pros:
The administration is great. The blend of the administration is hitting a groove that's helping to evolve the education at Cornish. 
Benefits package is GREAT! 
You can get an ORCA card to ride unlimited and software perks like ADOBE. 
The work environment is very low key because it's an arts school.
If you love the arts and entertainment, then you'll love the relationships you make here.
The main campus is in South Lake Union and so close to so many things. 
The students are amazingly talented and so are the faculty and staff.
There is a culture is wonderful.
cons:
Space is always an issue as Seattle continues to squeeze everyone around it. 
It would be nice to showcase the talented faculty more and students when possible.

review_title: associate professor, business manager, buyer, visual merchandiser
cons: Politics, Misunderstandings, Lack of administrative support

job_title: Digital Marketing Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: Beautiful campus, inspiring students, strong legacy in Seattle

review_title: Not sure if the ship is sinking but there are holes
pros:
Offers some opportunities for recent alumni. As an alum myself, I found this to be a huge pro. 

Pre-COVID travel perks as an Admissions Counselor. 

Currently however, there are little to no pros I can count, which is why I left.

There is a sense of community, however it’s limited to your area of focus- there is a huge invisible divide in the way we promote our performing arts versus our visual arts and the implications of that mean that the cons outweigh the pros.
cons:
The challenges the institution faces appear stronger than the culture and viability of the institution itself.

Little to no opportunities for growth or upward mobility.

Very very low staff/faculty satisfaction.

Lack of coordination and communication between departments.

Little to no diversity amongst faculty and staff.

Upper level administration doesn’t seem to listen to or take into consideration any input from outward facing teams who interact with the general public.

All pressure is on Admissions to increase numbers but little effort is done to increase retention.

Wages too low to sustain living in Seattle.

job_title: Fabrication Lab Technician in Seattle, WA
pros: Great people, fun day-to-day, good institutional support

An incredible community of creative individuals that are passionate about the school and its colorful history. It is a supportive group of Faculty, Staff and Students that are bubbling with innovative artistic practices.
cons:
The school is a behind in a lot of its essential needs. It is out of touch with it's external image and the leaders of the school are not receptive to the feedback and change needed to thrive in this decade.

The school is also incredibly inconsistent with hiring qualified fits for its positions and there is very little opportunity to move upwards.

pros: incredible students, colleagues, and important mission
cons: low confidence in upper administration, very low pay

pros:
Excellent coworkers
Good benefits
Supporting students' learning
Many industry events and opportunities to network.
Can really clock in and clock out if you want.
cons:
The pay is embarrassingly bad. IT IS SO BAD. Can't emphasize this enough. Unless you are independently wealthy, go somewhere else.

The upper level of administration is chaotic, opaque, and bombastic. Extremely unclear expectations and out of touch with how long implementation takes. Total top-down management style. Very little room to collaborate or innovate. All campus meetings are just a formality. Little interest in letting faculty and staff lead the way forward. Watch your back.

Poor personnel management is poor. There is little room for advancement and next to no career training or professional development resources. 

There are huge structural issues and massive up-heaves, all glossed over and unexplained.

Many systems are way behind the times and many departments are taking on the work of other departments. 

Overall, do not feel valued as an employee.

review_title: Great Community and Environment, but Low Pay
pros: Cornish provides several well-established and innovative programs and the students are great. Opportunity to have real impact in such a small school (less than 800 students, less than 200 staff/faculty). Staff members generally have creative or fine art background. Currently restructuring curriculums to be more innovative and contemporary.
cons: Aging facilities and disorganized leadership hurt the school. They pay staff poorly, and there are very few perks. Tuition is very high, yet admission standards are somewhat low - tuition-funded school = they need to admit as many students as they can. Transition to new curriculum has been bumpy and perhaps does not serve undergraduate students as well as it could.

review_title: Potentially great, stuck in a theoretical rut.
pros: Cornish has all the makings of a great art school -- location, facilities, history, community support, love of art...but it falls short in it's mandate.
cons: Cornish views its niche as provider of theoretical knowledge as opposed to practical.  Hard to pay your excessive student loan debt with theoretical dollars.  Doesn't support or respect adjunct professors.  Full time lack industry expertise.

review_title: Do meaningful work for poverty-level wages!
pros: Progressive, invested in nurturing independent thinkers.
cons: Core faculty members who shirk their responsibilities to meetings, etc.  Pressure placed on adjuncts to shape curriculum and yet have no room to advance at the college.  Basically, the college loves how successful we are in our artistic lives and wants to use our reputations, knowledge, clout, and thoughts for free.  Our research gives us no guarantee for a shot at advancement.  Because of this, the college hemorrhages great faculty and hangs onto complacent, staid teachers.

review_title: Good people, a fun environment. Good Job satisfaction
pros: Good people, fun environment. A very diverse work force and student base.  It's always great to see the new types of art that the students create. The staff is also very creative as a whole, and you are encouraged to express yourself as a staff member.
cons: Not a lot of room for growth.  Most positions are very underpaid in contrast to the same types of jobs at other colleges.

review_title: College experiencing great confusion, lack of leadership & financial crisis.
pros: Most employees are hard working and committed to the institution.  The College used to be a great fine & performing arts institution.  Great downtown location.
cons: President has no background in Higher Ed., president works well with those who kiss up to him, board is not providing direction, enrollment is falling,  college is experiencing a financial crisis which is creating a stressful environment for employees.

review_title: They hire very talented people... and then pay them garbage.
job_title: Communications Manager in South Seattle, WA
pros:
Great work/life balance, you can really phone it in if you want to.
Cred on the resume/art world
Amazing benefits IF you don't have a family or a spouse, otherwise they are completely unaffordable.
cons:
Leadership is totally lost and out of touch. This school is being run into the ground.
No room for advancement of continuing education of skills.

pros: Kind, empathetic, collegial working environment at the department level.  The work feels meaningful and I also have lots of fun here.
cons:
Huge amount of turnover in senior management in the past two years -- particularly sad about sudden departure of most recent interim president.  
Salaries are low in relation to cost of living in Seattle.

review_title: Print Lab Monitor is a great work study job
job_title: Print Lab Monitor in Seattle, WA
pros: Access and control of printers as a design student definitely had it's benefits.
cons: Late nights but that is to be expected for any job while a full time student.
Mismanaged, had to put up with sexual harassment (reported and nothing happened), extremely underpaid and overworked.
